bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 166, Number 193 (Thursday, November 12, 2020)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. YOUNG:H.R. 8751.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article I, Section 8, Clause 3[Page H5731]

item.title: Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act Fulfillment Act of 2020

latestAction.text: Committee on Energy and Natural Resources Senate Subcommittee on Public Lands, Forests, and Mining. Hearings held. With printed Hearing: S.Hrg. 116-382.

item.title: Unrecognized Southeast Alaska Native Communities Recognition and Compensation Act

latestAction.text: Read twice and referred to the Committee on Energy and Natural Resources.

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Natural Resources.

summary.text:
Unrecognized Southeast Alaska Native Communities Recognition and Compensation Act

This bill permits the Alaska Native residents of certain Alaska Native villages to organize as Alaska Native urban corporations and to receive certain settlement land.

bill.title: Unrecognized Southeast Alaska Native Communities Recognition and Compensation Act

item.title: Unrecognized Southeast Alaska Native Communities Recognition and Compensation Act
Unrecognized Southeast Alaska Native Communities Recognition and Compensation Act
To provide for the recognition of certain Alaska Native communities and the settlement of certain claims under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act, and for other purposes.

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Natural Resources.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
